insert.info: The main American Mathematical Society packages
Text is allowed only between \begin{document} and \end{document}.
The \title command declares text to be the title.
The \author command declares the author(s), where names is a list of authors separated by \and commands.
If used, the \date command declares the date, either with explicit arg for explicit date or with empty arg for no date. If not used, the current date will automatically be inserted by \maketitle.
This command generates a title on a separate title page%n- except in the article class, where the title normally goes at the top of the first page.
Put this command where you want the table of contents to go
The itemize environment produces a 'bulleted' list.%nEach item of an itemized list begins with an \item command.
The enumerate environment produces a numbered list.%nEach item of an enumerated list begins with an \item command.
The description environment produces a labelled list.%nEach item of the list begins with an \item[label] command.

The {label} argument is a piece of text that is inserted in a box to form the label.%nThe {spacing} argument contains commands to change the spacing parameters for the list.%nEach item of the list begins with an \item command.
\item[label] Hello
\begin{tabbing}%ntext \= more text \= still more text \= last text \\%nsecond row \> \> more \\%n\end{tabbing}
\begin{tabular}[pos]{cols}%ncolumn 1 entry & column 2 entry ... & column n entry \\%n...%n\end{tabular}

\multicolumn{cols}{pos}{text}%ncol, specifies the number of columns to span.%npos specifies the formatting of the entry: c for centred, l for flushleft, r for flushright.%ntext specifies what text is to make up the entry.
The \hline command draws a horizontal line the width of the table.
The \vline command draws a vertical line extending the full height and depth of its row.
The command \space gives you a space where you can't enter a space character.
The \enspace command inserts a horizontal space of 1/2em.
The \quad command inserts a horizontal space of 1em (1em being the width of M).
The \qquad command inserts a horizontal space of 2em.
The command \thinspace produces unbreakable and unstretchable space of 1/6em (same as \, in math mode).
The command \negthinspace produces unbreakable and unstretchable space of -1/6em (same as \, in math mode).
The \hspace command inserts an amount of skip of horizontal space.
The \hfill command inserts a rubber length which has no natural space but that can stretch horizontally as far as needed.
The \hrulefill command produces an infinite horizontal rubber length that LaTeX fills with a rule (that is, a line), instead of white space.
The \dotfill command produces an infinite horizontal rubber length that LaTeX fills with dots, instead of white space.
The \newpage command ends the current page
The \linebreak command tells LaTeX to break the current line at the point of the command.
The \pagebreak command tells LaTeX to break the current page at the point of the command.
The \bigskip command adds a 'big' vertical space.
The \medskip command adds a 'medium' vertical space.
The \smallskip command adds a 'small' vertical space.
The \vspace command inserts an amount of skip (positive, zero or negative) of vertical space.
The \vfill command inserts a rubber length which has no natural space but that can stretch vertically as far as needed.
The \newline command breaks the line right where it is.
\alert{text} (easyReview)
\comment{text}{comment} (easyReview)
\add{text} (easyReview)
\remove{text} (easyReview)
\replace{text}{replacement} (easyReview)
Turn on review comments in pdf
Turn off review comments in pdf
This command generates an in-text citation to the reference associated with the ref entry in the bib file
\footnote[number]{text}%nThe \footnote command places the numbered footnote text at the bottom of the current page.
The argument to \bibliographystyle refers to a file style.bst, which defines how your citations will look

\addbibresource{bibfile} specifies the location of a resource file for biblatex such as a .bib file. The filename should contain the extension (e.g. '\addbibresource{mybibliography.bib}'). You can only add one file per \addbibresource{} command (no comma-separated lists allowed). But you can use multiple commands.
The math environment can be used in both paragraph and LR mode
The LaTeX math environment can be used in both paragraph and LR mode
The displaymath environment can be used only in paragraph mode
\dfrac is an amsmath package shorthand for \displaystyle\frac...
\begin{array}{col1col2...coln}%ncolumn 1 entry & column 2 entry ... & column n entry \\%n...%n\end{array}
The equation environment centers one equation on the page and places the equation number in the margin.
The align environment vertically aligns multiple equations. You can do so in several equation columns. Use & sign for alignment and splitting into columns.

The alignat environment is a variation of the align environment and allows to explicitly specify the space between equation columns. For ex. use &\quad& as column separator. Give the number of columns as a parameter.
The flalign environment is an align environment that stretches space between equation columns as much as possible, leaving just enough space at the margin for the equation number.
The gather environment is used for multiple centered equations separated by \\, each having an equation number.
The multline environment is a variation of the equation environment used for equations that don't fit on one line. Use \\ to split lines. Lines between the first and the last one will be centered.
The equation* environment is an unnumbered equation environment.
The align* environment is an unnumbered align environment.
The alignat* environment is an unnumbered alignat environment.
The flalign* environment is an unnumbered flalign environment.
The gather* environment is an unnumbered gather environment.
The multline* environment is an unnumbered multline environment.
The cases environment provides a strucure that displays as a brace left to an array of lines with two left-aligned columns.
The split environment is similar to the multline environment but allows vertical alignment using & signs. There is no eqn number. Use inside displayed environments.
Negative thin space
3/18 of a \quad
4/18 of a \quad
5/18 of a \quad
regular whitespace
The \quad command inserts a horizontal space of 1em (1em being the width of M).
Twice the size of a \quad
